metadata.title: Complex Regional Pain Syndrome
anatomical location body part affected: Sympathetic nervous system, leading to presentation of symptoms over the skin and joints of the affected extremities
description: Chronic regional pain syndrome (CRPS) is characterized by chronic neuropathic pain that is disproportionate to and lasts longer than the injury causing it would normally indicate.(1,2,3,4,5)
There are two types of CRPS: type I results from soft-tissue  or bone injury and type II results from injury to a nerve(3)

reimbursement: Home transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) units may or may not be covered by insurance depending on type of coverage. Other than that consideration, no specific issues or information regarding reimbursement have been identified. Patient may be undergoing litigation or workers’ compensation claims
contraindications precautions to test: Avoid any physical activity after nerve blocks or whenever there is excessive hypoesthesia
If deep vein thrombosis (DVT) is suspected (presence of unilateral edema, erythema, tenderness), contact patient’s physician immediately

If acute compartment syndrome is suspected, refer patient to emergency department for immediate medical care. For more information on acute compartment syndrome, see  Clinical Review ... Compartment Syndrome, Acute  ; CINAHL Topic ID T708485
Remember that just touching the affected area may be painful. Maintain continuous contact to avoid the irritation of make-and-break  contact over sensitive areas(7)

causes pathogenesis: The underlying pathophysiology is unclear, complex, and multifactoriall(1,4,9)

CRPS is thought to be caused by exaggerated inflammatory response(8) in which trauma triggers release ofproinflammatory cytokines as well as neuropeptides that contribute to pain and inflammation(6,8,10)
Sensitization of the sympathetic nervous system occurs and may be accompanied by autonomic dysregulation as well asincreased pain(1)
CRPS type I, formerly known as reflex sympathetic dystrophy, most commonly occurs after a crush injury. CRPS type II,formerly known as causalgia, follows damage to a peripheral nerve(2)
Fracture is the most common precipitating injury, but CRPS can also occur after myocardial infarction, stroke, orcancer.(1,10)
Other common activities that lead to CRPS are sprains/strains, burns or cuts, nerve damage from surgery, limb immobility(casting), and nerve penetrations(6)
In 10% of cases, no precipitating cause can be identified(10)
risk factors: Risk factors include:–Smoking(6)–Female sex, particularly postmenopausal women(9,10)–Poor circulation and poor nerve health, which can impede healing(6)–Surgery on shoulder, distal radius, carpal tunnel syndrome, Dupuytren contracture(8,11)–Prolonged immobilization(1)

overall contraindications precautions: Contraindications/precautions Complaints of severe pain (more than is typical) after an injury may be associated with increased risk of CRPS Increased psychologic distress in patients with CRPS is associated with increased severity and duration Avoid any physical activity after nerve blocks or whenever there is excessive hypoesthesia Pain must be managed during treatments, as affected areas will be hypersensitive Aggressive strengthening and ROM activities are contraindicated and may cause extreme pain, edema, emotional distress, or fatigue Use caution with use of ice and heat as they may exacerbate symptoms in advanced cases
See specific  Contraindications/precautions to examination   and  Contraindications/precautions   under Assessment/

history of present illness.mechanism of injury or etiology of illne: Mechanism of injury or etiology of illness -Date of onset of original injury/event? Date of onset of CRPS symptoms? -Describe precipitating injury and how it was managed -Generally, prior to the onset of CRPS, a patient has had the extremity immobilized for a period or experienced some form of injury/trauma to the extremity(2) -In 10% of cases no or very minor trauma is reported(23) -Describe symptoms at onset -Have symptoms changed since onset? -When was CRPS diagnosis made? -Diagnosis is based on history and clinical examination and can take some time to be reached.(1,4) By the time CRPS is diagnosed, pain may already be severely affecting quality of life(1,4)

course of treatment.medical management: Medical management Document interventions that have been aimed at treating pain and/or disability Oral or topical pharmacological interventions, nerve blocking procedures, surgical sympathectomy, and neuromodulation techniques may be tried(12) Local anesthetic sympathetic nerve blockade is commonly used to treat CRPS(30) Results from a 2013 Cochrane review suggest there is very little published literature to support the use of local anesthetic sympathetic nerve blockade as the “gold standard” treatment for CRPS. Two RCTs that met the researchers’ inclusion criteria had very small sample sizes, limiting the conclusions on the efficacy of this procedure(30) Sympathectomy destroys the nerves involved in CRPS,(9) either surgically or via injection of agents such as phenol(24) Spinal cord or brain stimulation may be useful in decreasing pain in some patients(24) Results from a systematic review and meta-analysis  indicate that spinal cord stimulation (SCS) decreases pain and need for pain medications, increases perceived quality of life, and facilitates the resumption of employment in patients with CRPS type I(18) Authors of a small United Kingdom study involving 3 adults using SCS suggest that although patients report increased independence with activities, they also experience feelings of dependence on the SCS, a lack of control over their future, and a perceived lack of understanding of their condition by others(32)
course of treatment.medications: Medications for current illness/injury Topical analgesics, narcotics, corticosteroids, bisphosphonates,(33)antidepressants, and antiseizure drugs(2,3) Document use of NSAIDs Inquire if patient is compliant with medication regimen and if he or she feels it is effectively controlling symptoms Topical ketamine can reduce CRPS pain and central sensitization. Studies suggest topical ketamine can reduce allodynia and hyperalgesia but does not help with pain. IV ketamine may also be administered(1)  Results from a multicenter, double-blind  RCT in Italy suggest that patients with acute CRPS type I can achieve clinically significant improvements in pain and quality of life after receiving 4 IV infusions of neridronate, a bisphosphonate(33) Eighty-two  adults with CRPS type I were randomly assigned to either the neridronate group or a placebo group Subjects received 4 IV infusions of 100mg of neridronate over a 10-day  period Within the first 20 days after receiving neridronate, visual analog scale (V AS) scores decreased significantly over the placebo group. Over the next 20 days, selfreported  pain continued to decrease, whereas the placebo group remained unchanged After the 40-day  period, individuals in the placebo group were given the 4 doses of neridronate One year following the treatment intervention, none of the patients from both groups reported symptoms of CRPS type I Results from a 2013 Cochrane review suggest there is no evidence to support the use of topiramate, an antiepileptic drug, for the treatment of chronic neuropathic pain(34) Four RCTs with 1,684 participants met the inclusion criteria All studies had one or more sources of potential major bias There was no convincing evidence of efficacy of topiramate (200 to 400mg/day) over a placebo
diagnostic tests completed: The diagnosis of CRPS is largely made through clinical exam and through the process of ruling out other medical conditions(1,2)
Doppler ultrasound may be administered to rule out blood clots
Plain radiographs may be ordered to rule out an acute fracture, osteomyelitis, and neoplasm. They may show osteopenia(2)
course of treatment.alternative therapies: Document any use of home remedies (e.g., ice or heating pack) or alternative therapies (e.g., acupuncture) and whether they help
course of treatment.previous therapy: Document whether patient has had occupational or physical therapy for this or other conditions and what specific treatments were helpful or not helpful

history of present illness.aggravating easing factors: Patient may report pain in response to nonpainful stimuli such as touch or temperature. Other sources of pain aggravation include joint ROM(5) and emotional distress.(4) Does the patient have pain at rest?
history of present illness.body chart: Use body chart to document location and nature of symptoms. Pain may progress and eventually encompass the entire limb; in rare circumstances, pain spreads to other anatomical regions as well(4)
history of present illness.nature of symptoms: Document nature of symptoms (e.g., constant vs. intermittent, sharp, dull, aching, burning, numbness, tingling). Patient may report or present with hyperesthesia, allodynia, vasomotor changes, edema, atrophy, sweating disturbances, decreased strength, changes in the skin/nails, and tremor in the affected extremity.(1) Does the patient report fear of moving (kinesiophobia)?
history of present illness.rating of symptoms: Use a visual analog scale (V AS) or 0-10 scale to assess symptoms at their best, at their worst, and at the moment (specifically address if pain is present now and how much).The McGill Pain Questionnaire can be used. Patients are often more disabled by the fear of pain than the actual pain(1) -The pain is commonly rated moderate to severe -Results from a research study involving 61 individuals with CRPS type I indicate that a reduction of at least 3 cm on a 10 cm V AS is typically required for patients to consider treatment successful(13)
history of present illness.pattern of symptoms: Document changes in symptoms throughout the day and night, if any (A.M., mid-day,  P.M., night); also document changes in symptoms due to weather or other external variables. Any change with emotional disturbance/stress?
history of present illness.sleep disturbance: Document number of wakings/night. Due to the nature of the condition, a disruption in the patient's sleep pattern would be expected -Disruption of normal natural sleep due to pain may present as fatigue, irritability, and memory difficulties
history of present illness.other symptoms: Document other symptoms patient may be experiencing that could exacerbate the condition and/or symptoms that could be indicative of a need to refer to physician (e.g., fever, signs and symptoms of DVT, shortness of breath)  Barriers to learning -Are there any barriers to learning? Yes__ No__ -If Yes, describe _________________________

past medical history.previous history of same similar diagnos: Document whether patient has had CRPS in the past. Has the patient experienced similar symptoms after previous injuries?
past medical history.comorbid diagnoses: Ask patient about other problems, including diabetes, cancer, heart disease, complications of pregnancy, psychiatric disorders, orthopedic disorders, and recent infection. Patients may report having osteoporosis. Atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease, recent infection, and stroke are risk factors for CRPS CRPS may present in the context of another existing disabling condition (e.g., stroke or severe multiple trauma)
past medical history.medications previously prescribed: Obtain a comprehensive list of medications prescribed and/or being taken (including OTC drugs)
past medical history.other symptoms: Ask patient about other symptoms he or she may be experiencing

social and occupational history.vocation avocation and associated repeti: Is the patient employed? What is the nature of the work? What activities and tasks does the patient routinely perform? Does CRPS interfere with ability to perform work or hobbies?
social and occupational history.functional limitations assistance with A: Fine and gross motor impairment in the involved extremity would be expected. Note any assistive or adaptive devices the patient is currently utilizing to facilitate independence with ADLs
social and occupational history.living environment: Stairs, number of floors in home, with whom patient lives, caregivers, etc. Identify if there are barriers to independence in the home; any modifications necessary?

relevant tests and measures.general: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be ›Relevant tests and measures: (While tests and measures are listed in alphabetical order, sequencing should be appropriate to patient medical condition, functional status, and setting)
relevant tests and measures.anthropometric characteristics: Anthropometric characteristics –Pitting edema may be present in the dorsum of the hand or foot; measure with 0–3+  scale (0 = none present, 1+ = minimal, 2+ = moderate, 3+ = severe) –Girth and volumetric measurements if edema is present
relevant tests and measures.balance: Assess as indicated, especially if lower extremity is involved
relevant tests and measures.functional mobility: Functional mobility –Assess as indicated using a standardized test such as FIM
relevant tests and measures.gait locomotion: Gait/locomotion –Assess gait and ability to ambulate safely if applicable –The 10-meter  walk test (10MWT) is reported to be a valid and reliable measurement tool for lower-limb  functional assessment in patients with neurologic impairments(4) Integumentary integrity –Check and document integumentary changes -Inspect for open wounds -Document stage and size measurements of any wounds present -Note any drainage or odor from wound -Document if new granulation tissue has started to form -Document color and skin characteristics, abnormal nail growth, increased hair growth, excessive perspiration, glossy
relevant tests and measures.muscle strength: Muscle strength –Manual muscle testing of gross muscle groups -Muscles that are in close proximity to the symptoms will likely be impacted by pain and disuse(7) –If upper extremity is involved, grip and pinch strength should be tested using a dynamometer
observation inspection palpation includi: Gross mobility screen of affected joints compared to unaffected limb -A capsular pattern may be present in the shoulder (greatest limitation in external rotation and abduction)(7) -Often restricted wrist extension is found, coupled with restricted metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joint flexion(7)  •Motor function (motor control/tone/learning)
Assess for tremor, myoclonic action in the affected limb. Dystonia may be present in late stages
Bradykinesia, deficits in movement amplitude, and reduced frequency of movement have also been reported(25)
Difficulty moving the limb may be related to pain or to motor dyspraxia(4)
Fine motor tasks should be assessed in patients with upper extremity CRPS using a standardized test such as the 9 Hole Peg Test •Observation/inspection/palpation  (including skin assessment)

Palpate for temperature asymmetry -During the acute phase, the impaired extremity will likely feel warmer to the touch compared to the contralateral limb; during the chronic phase, the extremity generally feels cooler and there may be a blue tint to the skin(5)
Hair and nail changes on the affected extremity are common with CRPS(5)
Observe for muscle fasciculations or tremors in the affected extremity(5)
Note the presence of muscle atrophy(1)
relevant tests and measures.posture: Posture –Complete a postural assessment, noting asymmetry in sitting and standing –Patient may hold affected limb immobile due to extreme pain –Poor posture and alignment commonly result from protective guarding of the extremity and imbalanced use of muscles
relevant tests and measures.range of motion: Range of motion –Goniometric measurements of affected joints reflecting ROM impairments are a frequent finding(5)
relevant tests and measures.reflex testing: Reflex testing –Hyperreflexia is common(5) Self-care/activities  of daily living  (objective testing) –Self-assessment  questionnaires on functional ability -Radboud Skills Questionnaire(14) -Upper extremity functional (UEF) assessment -Disabilities of the Arm, Shoulder and Hand (DASH) Outcome Measure -Lower Extremity Functional Scale (LEFS) –Health-related  quality of life questionnaires -Short-Form  Health Survey of the Medical Outcomes Study (SF-36)
relevant tests and measures.sensory testing: Sensory testing –Evaluate response to temperature, pressure, light touch, proprioception, vibration, and pinprick and compare to the contralateral extremity(5) -Results from a study in the Netherlands suggest that impaired central processing of proprioceptive information is associated with CRPS(35) -Twenty-five  adults with CRPS were compared to 50 healthy subjects -Patients with CRPS presented with proprioceptive impairments (accuracy and precision of wrist joint position in both the affected and unaffected sides) -Subjects primarily overestimated wrist extension angles -There was an association between severity of motor impairment and proprioceptive impairment -Researchers concluded that it is important to identify the proprioceptive impairments in order to promote optimal
relevant tests and measures.oral structure and oral motor function: motor function  –Hyperesthesia is a frequent finding(7) –Refer patient to an occupational therapist (OT) or speech-language  pathologist (SLP) specializing in neurological rehabilitation in order to thoroughly assess other sensory impairments such as constructional apraxia, conductional dysphasia, dysgraphesthesia, and dysgraphia. These have been associated with chronic CRPS(31)
relevant tests and measures.perception: Perception –Hemisensory neglect has been reported in patients with CRPS(25) –The degree of body perception disturbance (BPD) can be assessed using the Bath CRPS Body Perception Disturbance Scale(4,26)

contraindications precautions: On patients with demand-type  cardiac pacemakers
Venous or arterial thrombosis or thrombophlebitis
Used in close proximity to diathermy treatment
Tissues vulnerable to hemorrhage or hematoma
Areas of skin irritation, damage, or lesions
Thoracic region in patients with small, slender, fragile body types or a history of cardiac problems
On the craniofacial or cervical region of patients with a history of stroke or seizures
Over the abdominal, lumbosacral, or pelvic regions during pregnancy
In patients with the inability to control movements
Hypertension  cold can lead to an increase in blood pressure
Avoid aggressive treatment with cold modalities over an acute wound
Avoid placement over superficial nerves for extended periods (> 1 hour)
Cold may be counterproductive if being used to facilitate muscle relaxation and reduce in pain in patients who do not tolerate the modality
Unhealed fractures and unreduced joint dislocations
other: Only those contraindications/precautions applicable to this diagnosis are mentioned below, including with regard to modalities. Rehabilitation professionals should always use their professional judgment

Patients with this diagnosis are at risk for falls; follow facility protocols for fall prevention and post fall-prevention instructions at bedside, if inpatient. Ensure that patient and family/caregivers are aware of the potential for falls and educated about fall-prevention  strategies. Discharge criteria should include independence with fall-prevention strategies
Avoid any physical activity after nerve blocks or whenever there is excessive hypoesthesia
Pain must be managed during treatments, as affected areas will be hypersensitive
Aggressive strengthening and ROM activities are contraindicated and may cause extreme pain, edema, emotional distress, or fatigue
Spinal flexion is contraindicated in patients with lumbar spine osteoporosis

Use caution with use of ice and heat, as they may exacerbate symptoms in advanced cases. Electrical stimulation may increase symptoms in patients with mechanical allodynia through stimulation of large myelinated A fibers(4)

assessment plan of care.diagnosis need for treatment: Patients with CRPS benefit from physical therapy to improve ROM, strength, and function and to decrease pain and hypersensitivity treatment(28) –Guidelines for physical and occupational therapy for CRPS recommend that all treatment programs should include a core of:(4) -desensitization  -neuromuscular reeducation, which might include graded motor imagery, mirror therapy, or other techniques to promote normalization of neuromuscular function -a progressive, active exercise program designed to promote improvement in ROM, strength, and endurance -activities designed to attain functional goals (i.e., weight-bearing  and gait for the lower extremity and fine motor tasks for the upper extremity) -a monitored home exercise program –Authors of a retrospective study found that ultrasound-guided dry needling (USGDN) in combination with standard physical therapy is an effective treatment option for persons with CRPS-1(38) -Based on a retrospective study in India of patients with CRPS from 2005 to 2014 involving 44 patients -Primary outcome measures used in this study include the Clinical Diagnostic Criteria (CDC), DASH, and ultrasonography -All patients received USGDN 3 times a week for up to 45–60  days to the muscles of the neck and upper extremities. Medications were given to patients with CRPS as well as standard physical therapy that included electrical modalities, myofascial release, and muscle stretching. Strengthening exercises occurred once pain was reduced by 50% -Long-term  maintenance of pain relief was limited to only one year . assessment plan of care.rule out: Rule out(5) –acute fracture or trauma –blood clot or DVT –cellulitis –chronic vascular insufficiency –fibromyalgia –septic arthritis –septic tenosynovitis –scleroderma –peripheral neuropathy plexitis –allergic reaction –localized joint inflammation –tendonitis –bursitis –compartment syndrome –malingering, conversion disorder deQuervain’sstenosing tenosynovitis(36) Glomus tumor(37)
prognosis: Mild cases of CRPS may resolve in weeks to months; however, spontaneous resolution occurs rarely(4)
CRPS may eventually lead to debilitating, permanent changes in the body, thereby causing emotional suffering(4)
Only 1 of 5 patients with severe CRPS will return to prior level of function(16)

High levels of anxiety, pain-related  fear, and disability are likely to result in poorer outcomes in patients with CRPS type 1. This suggests that interventions should be geared towards treating these psychological factors during early interventions(39)
assessment plan of care.referral to other disciplines: Referral to other disciplines Psychiatrist/psychologist for cognitive behavioral therapy Pain clinic Recreation therapist to facilitate movement through leisure/recreational activities Occupational therapy for difficulties with ADLs V ocational therapy CRPS support groups
other considerations: It is important for the therapist to motivate patients with risk factors for CRPS to move the injured limb safely.(7) Once CRPS has been diagnosed, intervention must be initiated as soon as possible to prevent progression of the condition

Results from a prospective, double-blind  study conducted in the Netherlands indicate that supplemental vitamin C can reduce the risk of CRPS following wrist fracture. The recommended dosage is 500 mg for 50 days.(17) This study has not been replicated(1)
Many patients report dissatisfaction with the amount of social support they receive
Family and friends often misunderstand or underestimate the severity of the pain because it is disproportionate to the injury(32)
treatment summary: Research evidence is limited regarding the efficacy of treatment for CRPS –Authors of a 2013 Cochrane review indicate there is a critical lack of high-quality  evidence for the effectiveness of most interventions for CRPS. It is difficult to develop an evidence-based  approach to managing CRPS until further larger trials are completed(24) -This Cochrane review included 6 previously published Cochrane reviews and 13 non-Cochrane  reviews -Trials were typically small and of variable quality -Graded motor imagery may be effective for pain and function compared with typical treatment intervention, and mirror therapy may be effective for individuals with poststroke CRPS –Authors of a systematic review of RCTs published during the period 2000–2012  indicate strong evidence for the efficacy of just 3 treatments: bisphosphonates, repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), and graded motor imagery(23) -Evidence was strong against 1 treatment (blockade with guanethidine) and moderate or limited against 14 other treatments -Overall, the level of evidence from RCTs for the efficacy of interventions to relieve pain in CRPS was unsatisfactory. Novel treatments have recently been effective in small RCTs. Larger studies with longer follow-up  are needed –Pain exposure physical therapy (PEPT) is a new treatment that has been evaluated in retrospective and prospective studies and found to be safe and possibly effective(27) -PEPT consists of a progressive-loading  exercise program and management of pain avoidance behavior without the use of specific CRPS medication or analgesics -PEPT aims to decrease kinesiophobia, pain behavior, and learned nonuse through functional activity -Pain relief itself is not a primary treatment goal -An increase in pain during or after the exercises and activities may occur -Patients are instructed in self-massage  and forced use of the affected limb in order to desensitize beyond their pain limits –Results from an Indian study indicate that the combination of high-frequency  TENS and exercise therapy may be more effective than the combination of low-frequency  TENS and exercise therapy or than exercise therapy alone to reduce pain associated with CRPS(19) -This study included 30 patients with CRPS who received high-frequency  TENS and exercise therapy, low-frequency TENS and exercise therapy, or exercise therapy alone –Results from a systematic review of physical therapy interventions for the treatment of CRPS type I suggest graded motor imagery can decrease pain in adult patients (> 18 years) with CRPS type I(20) -The review included 5 RCTs, 1 comparative study, and 5 case series -During graded motor imagery, the patient looks at a photograph of a foot or hand and imagines moving his or her affected hand or foot into the position depicted in the photograph. The patient progresses to moving both limbs into the position while watching the unaffected limb in a mirror(21) -The authors concluded there is solid evidence for the use of graded motor imagery but there is insufficient evidence for the use of other treatments such as stress loading therapy –Investigators in studies of treatment of CRP (28,29) emphasize the importance of an interdisciplinary approach that includes physical rehabilitation and cognitive behavioral therapy –It is suggested that the four key components to managing patients with CRPS are patient/caregiver education, intense physical rehabilitation, pain management, and psychological interventions(1,2,3,4,5) -Intense physical therapy programs, some as much as 6 hours per day, have been described -In refractory cases, inpatient admission for rehabilitation for several days to weeks(29) or a day-hospital  interdisciplinary approach can be successful and cost-effective  in managing individuals who have failed to improve with outpatient

decreased pain and edema: Pain reported on V AS, McGill Pain Questionnaire
A change in appearance of an affected area
improved function of the affected extrem: Self-assessment  questionnaires regarding functional ability–UEF assessment–DASH Outcome Measure–LEFS
for upper extremity: Improved performance of fine motor tasks/coordination–9 Hole Peg Test

maintenance or prevention: There is no evidence that early physiotherapy can prevent CRPS; however, early diagnosis and therapy are recommended to decrease suffering, improve function, and prevent complications such as contractures(4)
Encourage safe, gentle movements (ankle pumps, opening/closing fist) with patients at risk for developing CRPS (trauma or immobilization of an extremity)
Maintain increased weight-bearing  activities through the affected extremity with a home exercise program focused on weight-bearing  exercises
Focus on early mobilization for susceptible patients
Education about pain management techniques (e.g., relaxation techniques) and pacing (e.g., appropriate rest breaks, alternating tasks) may be helpful
